questions.text: What is true about Torus tubarius, which is formed by the cartilaginous part of the eustachian tube?

choices.text: Most common site of carcinoma nasopharynx
mucosal elevation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx

questions.solution:
Correct Option C:  mucosal elevation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx

  • Torus Tubarius is a mucosal elevation in the lateral aspect of the nasopharynx.
  • Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess - fossa of Rosenmuller (the commonest site for the origin of carcinoma).
  • Ridge extends from the lower end of the torus tubarius to the lateral pharyngeal wall – the salpingopharyngeal fold.

Option A: Associated with pharyngeal bursitis

  • The pharyngeal bursa is located in the adenoid mass's midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx.
  • Pharyngeal bursitis is an infection of the pharyngeal bursa, which is a median recess representing attachment of notochord to endoderm of the primitive pharynx.
  • Torus tubarius has no association with pharyngeal bursitis.

Option B: Most common site of carcinoma nasopharynx

  • The commonest site of origin Of carcinoma nasopharynx is the fossa of Rosenmuller, not the torus tubarius.

Option D: Gives rise to Rathke's pouch

  • Rathke's pouch is a diverticulum of nasopharyngeal mucosa that forms the anterior lobe of the pituitary.
  • Its track may persist in the cricopharyngeal canal and give rise to craniopharyngioma.
  • It has no association with Torus tubarius

questions.text: Please identify the structure shown in this endoscopic image of the nasopharynx.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fossa of Rosenmüller

Explanation:

  • The fossa of Rosenmüller is a common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma and is located posterior to the torus tubarius in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.
  • On endoscopic examination, it appears as a deep recess lateral to the Eustachian tube opening.

Nasopharyngeal Anatomy

Structure

Description

Fossa of Rosenmüller

Deep recess behind the torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Sinus of Morgagni

Gap between the base of the skull and superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle

Passavant’s Ridge

Muscular ridge formed by the superior pharyngeal constrictor, involved in velopharyngeal closure

Rathke’s Pouch

Embryological remnant from which the anterior pituitary gland develops

Incorrect Options:

Sinus of Morgagni (Option A): is incorrect because it is an anatomical gap at the skull base, not a recess seen in endoscopy.

Passavant’s Ridge (Option B): is incorrect because it is a transient muscular ridge formed during swallowing, not a fixed nasopharyngeal structure.

Rathke’s Pouch (Option D): is incorrect because it is an embryological structure related to pituitary gland development, not visible in nasopharyngeal endoscopy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought by her mother, with the complaint that the child is experiencing difficulties breathing through her nose. The girl's face appears elongated and lacks expression, and her mouth remains open. Upon examination, it is observed that she has a palate with a high arch and her upper teeth are crowded. An X-ray image is provided for reference. Based on these findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Adenoid hypertrophy.

Explanation:

  • The symptoms described- difficulty breathing through the nose, an elongated face, lack of expression, mouth-breathing, high-arched palate, and crowded upper teeth- are classic signs of adenoid hypertrophy.

  • Adenoid hypertrophy occurs when the adenoid tissue, located in the nasopharynx, becomes enlarged, obstructing airflow through the nasal passages.

  • This leads to mouth breathing, sleep disturbances, and characteristic facial features, including an elongated face and a high-arched palate due to the prolonged open-mouth breathing pattern.

Adenoid Hypertrophy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy is common in young children and can cause nasal obstruction, leading to mouth breathing and sleep disturbances (e.g., snoring, sleep apnea).

  • It may also result in facial deformities like the elongated face, high-arched palate, and crowded teeth due to chronic open-mouth breathing.

  • X-ray imaging typically shows enlargement of the adenoid tissue in the nasopharyngeal region.

Incorrect Options:

Lingual tonsils (Option A): is incorrect because while the lingual tonsils can contribute to obstructive symptoms, they are located at the base of the tongue, not in the nasopharynx.

Quinsy (Option B): is incorrect because quinsy refers to a peritonsillar abscess, typically presenting with severe throat pain, fever, and trismus, not with chronic nasal obstruction and facial deformities.

Tonsillar hypertrophy (Option C): is incorrect because tonsillar hypertrophy refers to the enlargement of the palatine tonsils, which is more likely to cause throat-related symptoms like difficulty swallowing, rather than the nasal obstruction seen in this case.

questions.text: Mark the false statement :

choices.text: Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of carotid sheath
Carotid sheath is formed by investing layer of deep cervical fascia
Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein
Common carotid artery divides at the level of lower border of thyroid cartilage

questions.solution:
The statement that is false is:

3. Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein.

Explanation of the options:

  1. Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of the carotid sheath: This statement is generally correct. The ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves from the cervical plexus, and it runs on the posterior wall of the carotid sheath.

  2. Carotid sheath is formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This statement is correct. The carotid sheath is a tubular structure that contains the common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. It is formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

  3. Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein: This statement is false. The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) typically runs alongside and posterior to the carotid sheath structures, including the internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein. It is located posterior to these structures, not between them.

  4. Common carotid artery divides at the level of the lower border of the thyroid cartilage: This statement is generally correct. The common carotid artery bifurcates into the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery at the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage in the neck.

So, the false statement is option 3, as the sympathetic chain is situated posterior to the structures within the carotid sheath, rather than between them.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient presented with throat pain and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, her right tonsil was found to be congested and uvula pushed to opposite side, left side tonsil was normal, what could be the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Quinsy

  • Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, shows the characteristic feature of severe pain in the throat, which is usually unilateral odynophagia that is difficult to swallow saliva. On examination, congested tonsils and uvula are pushed to the opposite side.
  • Quinsy is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus accumulates between the tonsillar capsule and the surrounding tissue.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Retropharyngeal abscess; A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection that develops in the space located behind the pharynx. It is more commonly seen in children and typically presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and a stiff neck. In the given scenario, the symptoms and examination findings do not suggest a retropharyngeal abscess.

Option B: Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis; refers to inflammation and infection of the tonsils. It typically presents with symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, fever, and enlarged and erythematous tonsils. However, the described examination findings of congested right tonsil and the pushing of the uvula to the opposite side are more indicative of a localized abscess, specifically quinsy, rather than generalized tonsillitis.

Option D: Parapharyngeal abscess; A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection that develops in the space adjacent to the pharynx, located between the pharyngeal muscles and the deep neck fascia. It can cause symptoms such as severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, neck pain, and swelling in the neck. However, the presented scenario describes findings consistent with a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) rather than a parapharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 2 day history of fever and difficulty in swallowing. On examination there was swelling seen in the oropharynx pushing tonsil to midline and swelling over the upper part of neck. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation described, the most likely diagnosis is 2. Parapharyngeal abscess.

Here's an explanation of the options:

  1. Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess): Quinsy is an abscess that forms in the peritonsillar space, which is located around the tonsils. It can cause severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and the tonsil on one side may be pushed toward the midline due to the accumulation of pus. While it shares some similarities with parapharyngeal abscess, the key difference is that quinsy specifically involves the peritonsillar space.

  2. Parapharyngeal Abscess: A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection and collection of pus located in the parapharyngeal space, which is situated behind the pharynx (throat) and extends into the upper part of the neck. It often presents with fever, difficulty swallowing, and swelling over the upper part of the neck, as described in the scenario.

  3. Retropharyngeal Abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection and collection of pus in the retropharyngeal space, which is located behind the throat and in front of the cervical spine. It can also cause difficulty swallowing and neck swelling. However, it typically presents in a different anatomical location compared to the parapharyngeal abscess.

  4. Tonsillitis: Tonsillitis is an infection or inflammation of the tonsils, which can cause sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. While tonsillitis may involve swelling of the tonsils, it doesn't typically cause the specific neck swelling described in the scenario.

questions.text: Deep lobe of parotid gland swelling presents at
questions.solution:
Correct Option D 

  • Parapharyngeal Space: This option is correct. The deep lobe of the parotid gland can extend into the parapharyngeal space, leading to swelling in that region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Below the ear lobe: This option is incorrect. Swelling below the ear lobe is not specific to the deep lobe of the parotid gland.

Option B - Cheek: This option is incorrect. While parotid gland swelling can cause cheek enlargement, it is not specific to the deep lobe.

Option C - Temporal lobe: This option is incorrect. The temporal lobe is a part of the brain and is not related to parotid gland swelling.

questions.text: Parotid gland is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option - B Glossopharyngeal:

  • Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve supply the parotid gland.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Facial Nerve: The facial nerve does not supply the parotid gland.

Option C - Vagus Nerve: The vagus nerve does not supply the parotid gland.

Option D - Hypoglossal Nerve: The hypoglossal nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the muscles of the tongue and does not supply the parotid gland.

questions.text: Which instrument is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct option A.

  •  A tongue depressor is a flat, thin, wooden or plastic instrument used to hold down the tongue during oral examinations or procedures. It helps to provide a clear view of the oral cavity and throat.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Doyen retractor: The Doyen retractor is a type of handheld retractor commonly used in abdominal surgeries. It has a curved blade and is used to retract and hold back abdominal organs and tissues during the procedure.

Option C - Self-retaining retractor: A self-retaining retractor is a type of retractor that can be locked in place to maintain the desired exposure during surgery. It typically has blades or prongs that can be adjusted and locked in position, freeing the surgeon's hands.

questions.text: What is the most frequent presentation of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy, which refers to enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, is the most common manifestation of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The cancerous cells in the nasopharynx can spread to the nearby lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Epistaxis (nosebleeds) can occur in nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most common manifestation.

Option B: Headache can occur in nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most common manifestation.

Option C: Nasal obstruction is a common symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most common manifestation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about Frey's Syndrome?

choices.text: Aberrant misdirection of parasympathetic fibers of auriculotemporal nerve
Botulinum toxin is one of the treatment suggested
Less chances with enucleation than paratidectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. Less chances with enucleation than parotidectomy:

This statement is incorrect. Enucleation, a surgical procedure to remove a tumor or lesion without removing surrounding tissue, does not prevent the aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibers. As a result, Frey's syndrome can still occur after enucleation, although it might be less severe compared to cases where extensive parotidectomy (removal of the parotid gland) is performed.

Frey's syndrome involves gustatory sweating due to the misdirection of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve. Botulinum toxin injections are a suggested treatment, and the condition can still occur after enucleation, although it is generally less severe than after parotidectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Gustatory sweating:

  • Frey's syndrome, also known as gustatory sweating, is characterized by sweating and flushing of the skin on the cheek during eating. It occurs due to aberrant regeneration of damaged postganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibers, which were originally destined for the parotid gland but now stimulate sweat glands and blood vessels in the skin.

Option B. Aberrant misdirection of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve:

  • This statement is accurate. Frey's syndrome results from the aberrant misdirection of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve to the sweat glands and blood vessels of the skin, leading to the characteristic symptoms of sweating and flushing during eating.

Option C. Botulinum toxin is one of the treatment suggested:

  • Botulinum toxin injections are a common treatment for Frey's syndrome. By injecting botulinum toxin into the affected area, the overactive sweat glands can be temporarily paralyzed, reducing symptoms of sweating and flushing. This statement is true.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Glossopharyngeal nerve

  • The ear pain sensation originating from the non-otologic source or outside the ear is called Referred Otalgia, also known as secondary otalgia.
  • In the case of tonsillitis, the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is primarily responsible for this condition.

Incorrect Options

Option B: The facial nerve controls the muscles of the face.

Option C: The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the face. It is not specifically responsible for transmitting pain signals from tonsillitis to the ear.

Option D: The vagus nerve mainly regulates the function of various organs in the thorax and abdomen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely cause for the complaints of a 9-year-old boy presenting with right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever, when the oral cavity examination shows no abnormalities in the external facial examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Quinsy:

  • Quinsy (Peritonsillar abscess): Quinsy is the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms. It typically follows an episode of acute tonsillitis and presents with fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing (odynophagia), pain referred to the ear, and trismus (difficulty opening the mouth).
  • The absence of abnormalities on oral examination and the external facial exam makes this a more probable diagnosis.

Pharyngitis (Option A): is incorrect because pharyngitis generally presents with sore throat and fever, but it typically does not cause significant difficulty in opening the mouth or severe ear pain as seen in this case. There is no mention of visible throat redness or swelling, which would be expected in pharyngitis.

Parotid abscess (Option B): is incorrect because a parotid abscess usually causes swelling in the parotid gland area, which is not described here. Though ear pain is a symptom, there is no external facial swelling or pus drainage from the duct, which are typical signs of a parotid abscess.

Bezold’s Abscess (Option C): is incorrect because Bezold's abscess is a deep neck abscess that occurs as a complication of mastoiditis, usually presenting with swelling in the neck or behind the ear. The absence of such features and mastoiditis symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely in this case.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a patient who has a two-day history of fever, with a neck swelling and displacement of one tonsil towards the midline upon examination?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Parapharyngeal abscess: This is the correct option. A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection that occurs in the space behind the tonsil and next to the pharynx. It can cause swelling in the neck and displacement of the tonsil towards the midline, which matches the patient's presentation.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Quinsy: Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, is a complication of tonsillitis. It involves the collection of pus between the tonsillar capsule and the surrounding tissues. While it can cause swelling in the neck, it typically presents with severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a "hot potato" voice. The patient in the scenario does not exhibit these typical symptoms, making quinsy less likely.

Option C. Retropharyngeal abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection that occurs in the space behind the pharynx and in front of the cervical vertebrae. It typically presents with neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and a stiff neck. The patient in the scenario does not exhibit these typical symptoms, making retropharyngeal abscess less likely.

Option D. Tonsillitis: Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils and can present with symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and fever. While the patient in the scenario has a fever, the presence of a swelling in the neck and the displacement of the tonsil towards the midline suggests a more localized infection, making tonsillitis less likely.

questions.text: From the first pharyngeal arch, which muscle originates among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Anterior belly of digastric muscle:

  • Anterior belly of digastric muscle: This option is correct. The anterior belly of the digastric muscle originates from the first pharyngeal arch. It plays a role in opening the mouth and depressing the mandible.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Stapedius muscle: The stapedius muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It arises from the second pharyngeal arch and is involved in the movement and stabilization of the stapes bone within the middle ear.

Option C- Posterior belly of digastric muscle: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle does not originate from the first pharyngeal arch. It arises from the second pharyngeal arch and assists in the movement of the hyoid bone.

Option D- Stylopharyngeus: The stylopharyngeus muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It originates from the third pharyngeal arch and helps elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speech.

  • In summary, the muscle that originates from the first pharyngeal arch is the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the spasm causing trismus in parapharyngeal abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Medial pterygoid: The spasm of the Medial pterygoid muscle can cause trismus in parapharyngeal abscess. This muscle is involved in closing the jaw.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Lateral pterygoid: The Lateral pterygoid muscle is responsible for protrusion and side-to-side movements of the jaw, but it is not directly associated with trismus in parapharyngeal abscess.

Option C. Masseter: The Masseter muscle is one of the main muscles involved in closing the jaw. However, in parapharyngeal abscess, the spasm of the Medial pterygoid muscle is primarily responsible for trismus.

Option D. Temporalis: The Temporalis muscle is another muscle involved in closing the jaw. However, it is not specifically associated with trismus in parapharyngeal abscess.

  • In summary, the correct muscle responsible for trismus in parapharyngeal abscess is the Medial pterygoid muscle (option A). It is important to note that proper diagnosis and treatment by a healthcare professional are essential for managing this condition.

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options does not represent a premalignant lesion or condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis: Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. It is not considered a premalignant lesion or condition.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Oral submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucosal fibrosis is a chronic, progressive condition characterized by the formation of fibrous bands in the oral cavity. It is associated with the habitual use of betel quid, tobacco, and certain spices. It is considered a premalignant condition because it carries an increased risk of developing oral squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an autoimmune condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral mucosa. While lichen planus itself is not considered premalignant, it has been associated with an increased risk of oral squamous cell carcinoma in some cases.

Option D. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia refers to white or gray patches that develop on the mucous membranes, including the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant lesion because it has the potential to transform into oral cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not innervated by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Palatoglossus: This is the correct option. The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) does not supply the palatoglossus muscle. The palatoglossus muscle is innervated by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). Therefore, option A is correct.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Styloglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the styloglossus muscle. The styloglossus muscle is responsible for retracting and elevating the tongue. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C. Genioglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the genioglossus muscle. The genioglossus muscle is the main muscle responsible for protruding and retracting the tongue. It plays a crucial role in swallowing and speech. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D. Hyoglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the hyoglossus muscle. The hyoglossus muscle helps depress and retract the tongue. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which muscle among the options provided functions as an accessory muscle in the process of mastication?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • This is the correct option. The buccinator muscle is an accessory masticatory muscle. It is a flat, thin muscle located in the cheek region. The buccinator muscle plays a role in actions such as compressing the cheeks against the teeth, assisting in chewing and swallowing, and maintaining oral competence. Therefore, option A is correct.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Masseter: The masseter muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but one of the primary muscles involved in mastication (chewing). It is a powerful muscle located at the side of the face, covering the jawbone. The masseter muscle is responsible for the elevation and protrusion of the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but another primary muscle involved in mastication. It is located on the inner side of the mandible and functions in elevating and protruding the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D. Lateral pterygoid: The lateral pterygoid muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but one of the primary muscles involved in mastication. It is located in the region of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and is responsible for the forward movement (protrusion) and lateral movement (side-to-side) of the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A patient comes with an ulcer on the tongue with a duration of 3 months. On examination, there is a 3.5cm x 2.5 cm lesion with induration of 8mm. There was no lymphadenopathy. What is the stage of this lesion according to 8the AJCC guidelines ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The staging of oral cavity cancers, including tongue cancer, is typically based on the guidelines provided by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC). The AJCC staging system takes into account various factors, including the size of the primary tumor (T), the presence of regional lymph node involvement (N), and the presence of distant metastasis (M).
  • In this scenario, the patient presents with an ulcer on the tongue that has been present for 3 months. The examination reveals a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm with an induration (hardening) of 8 mm. However, there is no lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes). Based on this information, we can determine the stage of the lesion.
  • According to the AJCC guidelines for oral cavity cancer, the T category is based on the size and extent of the primary tumor. In this case, the size of the lesion is 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm, which corresponds to a T3 tumor (greater than 4 cm in greatest dimension). The induration of 8 mm indicates invasion beyond the submucosa.
  • The N category, which assesses regional lymph node involvement, is determined by the absence or presence of lymphadenopathy. Since there is no lymphadenopathy reported in the scenario, the N category is N0 (no regional lymph node involvement).
  • Based on the T and N categories, the staging can be determined. According to the AJCC guidelines, the combination of a T3 tumor (size >4 cm with invasion beyond submucosa) and N0 (no regional lymph node involvement) corresponds to Stage II.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Stage I. Stage I is typically characterized by smaller tumors, usually less than 2 cm in greatest dimension, without evidence of invasion beyond the submucosa. In this scenario, the size of the lesion is larger than 2 cm, and there is evidence of invasion beyond the submucosa, making it inappropriate to classify it as Stage I.

Option C: Stage III. Stage III usually indicates larger tumors with extensive local invasion or regional lymph node involvement. In this scenario, there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement, making Stage III an incorrect classification.

Option D: Stage IV. Stage IV typically indicates advanced disease with extensive local invasion, regional lymph node involvement, and/or distant metastasis. Since there is no lymphadenopathy reported and no mention of distant metastasis in the scenario, Stage IV is not the appropriate classification.

questions.text: A patient presents with oral cavity findings are seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient ?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • In the given scenario, the patient presents with a wrinkled white patch on the ventral surface of the tongue, which is consistent with leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a potentially premalignant condition characterized by persistent white patches or plaques that cannot be wiped away and cannot be attributed to any other known cause.
  • Since the patient is a smoker, it increases the suspicion of the lesion being potentially malignant. Therefore, the next step in the management of this patient would be to immediately address the most significant risk factor, which is smoking. The patient should be advised to cease smoking as it plays a crucial role in the development and progression of oral cavity lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Giving corticosteroids: Corticosteroids may have some anti-inflammatory properties, but they are not the primary management option for leukoplakia. The use of corticosteroids in the absence of a definitive diagnosis and appropriate risk assessment is not recommended.

Option C. Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modification is generally beneficial for overall health, it is not sufficient as the next step in the management of leukoplakia. The presence of a potentially premalignant lesion requires a more focused and immediate approach.

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause oral manifestations, but it is not the appropriate next step in managing leukoplakia. Vitamin B12 supplementation may be indicated if there is evidence of deficiency, but it does not address the underlying risk factors or provide a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1

2.    Vocal cord palsy: Infection in the parapharyngeal space can potentially cause compression or involvement of the cranial nerves, including the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Damage to this nerve can result in vocal cord palsy, affecting the movement of the vocal cords.

3.Parotid swelling: Parotid swelling is typically not a direct manifestation of an infection in the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space. The parotid gland is located outside this space. Parotid swelling could occur in other conditions, such as parotitis (inflammation of the parotid gland), but it is not a direct consequence of parapharyngeal space infection.

4. Horner's syndrome: Horner's syndrome results from a disruption of sympathetic nerve pathways, typically involving damage to the sympathetic nerves in the neck. Infection in the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space may not directly affect the sympathetic nerves responsible for Horner's syndrome. However, it can cause other neurological symptoms related to cranial nerves and structures in that area.

questions.text: A middle-aged lady choked while eating fish and has associated symptoms of coughing, hoarseness of voice, and a foreign body sensation in the throat. On examination, the pyriform fossa is found to be inflamed. Which of the following nerves supplies this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Internal Laryngeal Nerve (ILN)

  • Pyriform fossa sensation: The pyriform fossa (or piriform sinus) is a depression on each side of the laryngeal inlet. It is exquisitely sensitive to foreign bodies and is innervated by the internal laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • Internal Laryngeal Nerve (ILN) (Option A): The internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (which in turn is a branch of the vagus nerve). It is responsible for sensory innervation above the vocal cords, including the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and the pyriform fossa.
  • External Laryngeal Nerve (ELN) (Option B ruled out): The external laryngeal nerve is primarily motor, supplying the cricothyroid muscle (which tenses the vocal cords). It has very little sensory function, and not to the pyriform fossa.
  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve (Option C ruled out): The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, tonsils, and part of the pharynx, but not directly to the pyriform fossa.
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option D ruled out): The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is primarily motor to most intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except the cricothyroid) and provides sensory innervation below the vocal cords. It does not supply the pyriform

questions.text: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is most strongly associated with which of the following head and neck cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Oropharyngeal carcinoma

Explanation:

  • HPV, especially HPV-16, is strongly linked to oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, involving sites such as the tonsils and base of tongue.
  • These cancers often occur in younger, non-smoking individuals, have a better prognosis, and are driven by the E6 and E7 viral oncoproteins that inactivate p53 and Rb tumor suppressor pathways.
  • In the clinical context, HPV testing is important for prognosis and treatment planning, as HPV-positive tumors respond better to chemoradiotherapy.
  • HPV
    • HPV 6 and 11 cause juvenile respiratory papillomatosis which rarely undergoes malignant change
    • Sexual behaviors and HPV infection are strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, but there is limited epidemiological evidence connecting these factors with laryngeal cancers.
    • Unlike oropharyngeal cancer, current studies do not show an improved prognosis for HPV-positive laryngeal tumors.

Incorrect Options:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option A): Strongly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection, not HPV.
  • Hypopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B): More commonly linked to tobacco and alcohol abuse rather than HPV infection.
  • Laryngeal carcinoma (Option C): Usually related to smoking and alcohol; HPV may play a minor role but not the strongest association.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old child with symptoms of throat pain, fever, and ear pain, the diagnosis is recurrent tonsillitis. Which specific nerve is associated with the ear pain in this patient?

choices.text: Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
Auricular branch of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is provides sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and middle ear.
  • The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as Jacobson's nerve, provides sensory innervation to the middle ear cavity and the eustachian tube.
  • In cases of middle ear infections or inflammation, such as those associated with tonsillitis, stimulation of this nerve can cause pain in the ear.

Incorrect Options:

Greater auricular nerve (Option B):

  • The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the cervical plexus and provides innervation to the skin on the side of the head and neck, including the area around the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option C):

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the temporal region, including the area in front of the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Option D):

  • The auricular branch of the vagus nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the vagus nerve and provides innervation to the skin of the ear canal and outer ear. However, it is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image below
questions.solution:
The Buccopharyngeal fascia is a thin connective tissue layer that covers the outer surface of the pharynx and esophagus. It is part of the deep cervical fascia and plays a key role in supporting the pharyngeal wall and separating it from adjacent structures. It encloses the pharyngeal constrictor muscles and extends from the base of the skull down to the esophagus.

 

It is continuous with the pretracheal fascia anteriorly and blends with the adventitia of the esophagus inferiorly.

This fascia contains the pharyngeal venous plexus and forms an important anatomical barrier between the pharynx and the retropharyngeal space.

Other Options:

 

Prevertebral fascia (Option B): Covers the vertebral column and associated muscles (not the pharynx).

 

Pharyngobasilar fascia (Option C): Lies deep to the pharyngeal muscles and helps attach the pharynx to the skull base.

 

Alar fascia (Option D): A thin layer between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fasciae, forming part of the retropharyngeal space.

questions.text: Impaired gag reflex is caused by a lesion in which of the following cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CN IX and X:

  • The sensory supply of the oropharynx is via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), and the motor supply is via the vagus nerve (CN X), so any lesion in these nerves will lead to an impaired gag reflex.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nasopharyngeal airway:

  • The given image shows a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) device or "nasal trumpet." It is a hollow plastic or soft rubber tube that can improve oxygenation and ventilation in cases where bag-valve-mask ventilation is ineffective.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA):

Option C - NG tube:

 

Option D - Oropharyngeal tube:

questions.text: Identify the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Explanation:

  • It has two valves-one connected to the trachea and other valve to esophagus
  • Provox and Blom singer are some of its types.

 

Incorrect Options:

Montgomery tube (Option A): This instrument works like a stent to keep the lumen patent whenever there is subglottic and tracheal resection done.

BAHA (Option C): Bone anchored hearing aid is used for patient with hearing loss especially conductive hearing loss

PORP prosthesis (Option D): This is used in ossicular chain reconstruction/Ossiculoplasty

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - JNA:

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare, benign, vascular tumor of nasopharynx exclusively seen in the juvenile age group and in males.

  • Most common site of origin is sphenopalatine foramen.

  • Clinical features include:

    • Recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis

    • Anemia

    • Nasal obstruction- Hyponasal speech and frog face deformity

    • Eustachian tube obstruction

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Allergic rhinitis:

  • Allergic rhinitis presents with paroxysmal sneezing, nasal obstruction, iching in the nose, watery nasal discharge, asthma, dryness of the skin.

Option C - Coagulation disorder:

  • Coagulation disorders does not present with unilateral nasal obstruction.

Option D - Antrochoanal polyp:

  • Antrochoanal polyp does not present with profuse recurrent epistaxis.

questions.text: Which structure is typically involved in causing lower lip paralysis following a parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Facial-main trunk of FN

  • The lower lip is supplied by the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve will cause paralysis of lower lip.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

(Option A) Facial-cervical branch:

  • Cervical branch injury can be distinguished from marginal mandibular nerve injury by the fact that the patient will be able to evert the lower lip because of a functioning mentalis muscle.

(Option C) Facial-temporal part:

  • Injury to the temporal part of the facial nerve leads to paralysis of the upper part of the face.

(Option D) Parotid duct:

  • Injury to the parotid duct is not related to lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: What is the preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing chronic nasal obstruction and sleep apnea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Adenoidectomy

Explanation:

  • The preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing nasal obstruction and sleep apnea is adenoidectomy.

Management of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

Medical Management: (For Mild Cases initially)
  • Breathing exercises
  • Decongestant nasal drops
  • Antihistamines for any nasal allergies
  • Topical Nasal Steroids may reduce adenoid size and improve related symptoms.

Surgical Intervention: (Adenoidectomy)
  • Traditional Methods: Blind curettage adenoidectomy remains common, but it has disadvantages, including unpredictable bleeding and poor access to the choanal adenoid. Hence, Endoscopic management is currently preferred.
  • Direct Vision Techniques:
    • Suction Diathermy
    • Endoscopic Coblation/Microdebridement involves using endoscopy to visualise and allows for precise removal of obstructive adenoid tissue, addressing the underlying issue directly.
    • KTP Laser: Associated with a higher risk of nasopharyngeal stenosis, while the gold laser has not shown this risk.

Incorrect Options:

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion (Option B): would be the answer if the patient had serous otitis media with failed medical therapy (steroid nasal spray).

Antibiotic therapy (Option C): is usually preferred in an acute tonsillitis case.

Watchful waiting (Option D): Since the patient is symptomatic watchful waiting is not appropriate.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ranula

Explanation:

  • A ranula is a type of mucocele that occurs when a salivary gland duct, typically the sublingual gland duct, becomes blocked or damaged, leading to the accumulation of saliva in a cystic structure. This results in a painless, translucent or bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth as shown in the image
  • Treatment: marsupialisation

 

Pleomorphic adenoma (Option B) is the most common salivary gland tumor with an epithelial and mesenchymal component, commonly occurring in the parotid gland located in front, below & behind the ear lobule, pushing it up.

Ludwig angina (Option C) typically presents with a rapidly spreading, firm, and symmetrical swelling in the submandibular (below the jaw) and sublingual (under the tongue) spaces. The swelling may extend to the neck and cause a "woody" or indurated texture. It is also associated with features like fever, drooling, neck pain, and difficulty swallowing.

Dermoid cysts (Option D) usually present as a well-defined, raised mass under the skin. The size can vary from small to large.The surface of the dermoid cyst is usually smooth and can appear skin-colored or slightly discolored. It may resemble normal skin or have a slightly yellowish hue.

questions.text: What is the most common site of ranula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Floor of the mouth:

  • A ranula is a type of mucocele that occurs in the floor of the mouth. It is a cystic swelling that develops due to the obstruction of the salivary gland duct, most commonly the sublingual gland duct. The sublingual gland is located beneath the tongue and its duct can become blocked, leading to the accumulation of saliva and the formation of a cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. Ranulas can vary in size and may cause discomfort or interfere with speech and swallowing.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tonsil: A ranula is not associated with the tonsil. Tonsils are lymphoid tissue masses located at the back of the throat and are part of the immune system, helping to protect against infections. Conditions related to tonsils could include tonsillitis, but not ranulas.

Option C - Uvula: A ranula does not typically occur on the uvula. The uvula is the small, fleshy mass of tissue that hangs down at the back of the throat. Conditions affecting the uvula could include uvulitis (inflammation of the uvula), but ranulas are not associated with this structure.

Option D - Cingula: The term "cingula" might be a bit confusing in this context. The cingulum is a term used in dentistry to refer to the raised, rounded area on the lingual surface of anterior teeth. It's not related to the location of a ranula.

questions.text: A child with a mild cold who also has adenoid facies has been identified as having chronic adenoid hypertrophy. Which is the best surgical management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coblator:

  • For a child with chronic adenoid hypertrophy and adenoid facies, the best surgical management option among the given choices is Option A: Coblator. This technique offers precise tissue removal with minimal damage, reduced postoperative pain, and faster recovery

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Microdebrider: A microdebrider is a surgical instrument that uses suction and a rotating blade to remove tissue. It is another option for performing adenoidectomy. While it offers precise removal of tissue, it may generate more postoperative bleeding compared to Coblation. Microdebrider-assisted adenoidectomy can also be effective in treating chronic adenoid hypertrophy.

Option C - Curettage: Curettage involves scraping or scooping out tissue using a curette, a surgical instrument with a spoon-shaped end. While this technique was used in the past, it has largely been replaced by more advanced methods like Coblation and microdebrider due to their advantages in terms of reduced bleeding, decreased postoperative pain, and improved recovery.

Option D - Breathing exercise and symptomatic treatment: This option involves non-surgical management of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. Breathing exercises and symptomatic treatments may help manage the symptoms associated with adenoid hypertrophy, but they do not address the underlying issue of enlarged adenoid tissue. In cases where the adenoids are significantly enlarged and causing persistent symptoms, surgical intervention is often recommended to provide more effective and long-lasting relief.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the yellow arrow in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

  • The structure marked in the image is the Fossa of Rosenmüller
  • The Fossa of Rosenmüller is a small indentation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx located behind the posterior opening of the nasal cavity. In an image, it may appear as a small, rounded depression in the nasopharynx tissue on either side.

Incorrect Options:

Tubal Tonsil (Option B):

  • The Tubal Tonsil is a lymphoid tissue near the Eustachian tube’s opening. It is typically found in the superior aspect of the nasopharynx and may appear as a small, rounded tissue mass in an image.

Opening of Eustachian tube (Option C):

  • The opening of Eustachian tube is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, near the posterior border of the nasal cavity. It may appear as a small, slit-like opening in an image.

Adenoids (Option D):

  • A rectangular mass of lymphatic tissue called the adenoids is present in the nasopharynx.
  • The adenoids on the nasopharynx's roof and back wall are midline structures.
  • They are a component of the Waldeyer ring, which also consists of the adenoids, palatine tonsils, and lingual tonsils. Beginning in the seventh month of pregnancy, they typically develop until they reach adulthood.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with Hollman miller's sign in the CT image given below?
questions.solution:
Holman-Miller sign (also called the antral sign) refers to the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus seen on CT imaging. This is a classic radiological feature of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA).


 

Investigations of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan
  • Investigation of choice; shows tumor size, location, and bony involvement.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Holman-Miller sign (bowing of maxillary wall).

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Evaluates soft tissue and intracranial extension, differentiates between extradural and intradural spread.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Visualizes tumor vascularity, identifies feeding vessels and aids in preoperative embolization to reduce surgical blood loss.

Nasopharyngoscopy

Provides a direct view of the tumor, but biopsy is generally avoided due to high bleeding risk.

Audiometry

Assesses hearing loss caused by Eustachian tube obstruction; establishes baseline and monitors post-treatment hearing.

Biopsy

Biopsy is contraindicated due to risk of profuse bleeding.


 

Other Options:

 

Maxillary sinusitis (Option B): Causes mucosal thickening and fluid collection but does not produce bony bowing.

 

Nasal polyp (Option C): Soft tissue lesion without bony remodeling or aggressive expansion.

 

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D): Fungal infection causing friable polypoid masses but does not cause the Holman-Miller sign.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophagoscopy

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a radiopaque foreign body in the esophagus, which is a common foreign body ingestion in children.
  • Esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both diagnosing and safely removing the foreign body.
  • The esophagus is the likely location when the object’s flat surface is seen on the anteroposterior (AP) X-ray because coins align flatly in the esophagus, unlike in the trachea, where the edge appears in the AP view.

 

 

Foreign body in esophagus:

Category

Indications

Management
Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects
 Immediate endoscopic removal
Urgent
  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks
 Observation

Bronchoscopy (Option A): is not appropriate as the foreign body is in the esophagus and not the airway.

Tracheostomy (Option C): is not necessary as the airway is not obstructed.

Heimlich's maneuver (Option D): may be appropriate for foreign bodies in the trachea and choking due to food or other material.

questions.text: What would be the next step in managing the symptoms of a 7-year-old child who underwent a tonsillectomy and now presents with snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing, a slight hearing loss, a high arched palate, and a decline in school performance, causing concern to the mother?
questions.solution:
The next course of treatment for this youngster would be an adenoidectomy with grommet insertion based on the symptoms and examination results. Snoring, mouth breathing, and a minor loss of hearing in the children are indications that the upper airway may be blocked, possibly as a result of swollen adenoids. The child's breathing would be made better by an adenoidectomy by removing the adenoids. Grommets would facilitate greater middle ear fluid outflow, enhancing the child's hearing. Adenoidectomy and grommet insertion may help the child's symptoms, which may also be caused by the child's high-arched palate.

Incorrect choices:

Option a: Adenoidectomy: In some instances where swollen adenoids are the cause of upper airway obstruction, adenoidectomy alone may be adequate. However, the child in this instance also has a high arched palate and a slight hearing loss, which indicates that there may be additional factors causing his symptoms.

Option b: Myringoplasty: A surgical treatment called myringoplasty can be used to seal an eardrum hole. However, in this instance, the child's primary symptoms are obstruction of the upper airway. Myringoplasty is not a suitable course of treatment for this reason.

Option d: Conservative management: For some cases of upper airway blockage brought on by enlarged adenoids, conservative care, such as observation and symptomatic treatment, may be suitable. The child's symptoms are, however, impacting his academic performance in this instance, and consequences could arise if the obstruction is not removed. The child's symptoms may not be sufficiently addressed and his quality of life may not be improved by conservative management, for this reason.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound compressing the swelling. X-ray of the neck is seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a professional trumpet blower with a swelling on the side of the neck, associated with a gurgling sound upon compression, strongly suggests a laryngocele. A laryngocele is an abnormal air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that can communicate with the laryngeal lumen. It is often seen in individuals who engage in activities requiring frequent or high-pressure breathing, such as wind instrument players or glassblowers.
  • Key clinical features of a laryngocele:
    • Swelling in the neck that may increase in size with activities like blowing.
    • Gurgling sound or fluctuation on palpation if it contains mucus or air.
    • Can present as an internal, external, or mixed type (external is visible as a neck swelling).

Incorrect Options:

Pharyngeal pouch (Option A): Typically presents with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and a swelling that may gurgle but is located posterior to the pharynx. It is not associated with trumpet blowing or activities requiring forced expiration.

Trachea-oesophageal fistula (Option C): This is a congenital or acquired condition presenting with recurrent aspiration, coughing, and feeding difficulties. It does not cause a compressible neck swelling or gurgling sound.

Tonsillar cyst (Option D): This would present as a localized swelling near the tonsillar region without the gurgling sound or association with forced expiratory activities.

questions.text: What is the most probable condition for a 6-year-old child who has not received immunization, presented to the Emergency Room by a concerned mother, experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing? Physical examination reveals the presence of a pseudo membrane on the tonsils that bleeds upon attempted removal, as well as a swollen neck giving a bull-neck appearance.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diphtheria

Explanation:

The described clinical presentation is most consistent with diphtheria, a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Key findings that support this diagnosis include:

  1. Pseudo membrane on tonsils: A hallmark feature of diphtheria, this greyish membrane adheres firmly to the underlying tissue and bleeds upon removal.
  2. Bull-neck appearance: Swelling of the neck due to cervical lymphadenopathy and soft tissue oedema is a classic sign of diphtheria.
  3. Fever, cough, and difficulty breathing: These are common systemic and respiratory symptoms of diphtheria.
  4. No immunisation history: The lack of vaccination increases susceptibility to diphtheria, which is preventable through the DPT vaccine.

Causes of Membrane over the tonsils include:

  • Moniliasis (Candidiasis)
  • Diphtheria (pseudomembrane)
  • Vincent’s angina (pseudomembrane)
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Malignancy of tonsil
  • Trauma
  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Leukaemia
  • Agranulocytosis

 

Infectious mononucleosis (Option A): While it may cause tonsillar swelling and pharyngitis, it does not cause a pseudomembrane or bull-neck appearance. Bleeding upon removal of the membrane is also not characteristic.

Tonsillitis (Option B): Tonsillitis can cause fever and difficulty swallowing, but it does not produce a pseudomembrane or bull-neck swelling. It is usually due to bacterial (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes) or viral infections.

Candidiasis (Option D): Oral candidiasis can cause white patches on the mucosa, but these are easily scraped off without bleeding, unlike the pseudomembrane in diphtheria. It is also less likely to cause systemic symptoms like bull-neck swelling.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions does not result in the development of a grey-white membrane over the tonsils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ludwig’s angina

Explanation:

  • Ludwig's angina is a deep neck space infection involving the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces. It does not produce a grey-white membrane over the tonsils. Instead, it is characterised by swelling of the floor of the mouth, raised tongue, and difficulty in breathing, speaking, or swallowing.

 

Ludwig’s angina- Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces.
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces

 
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis (Option A): Although rare, severe forms can lead to exudative tonsillitis, with grey-white deposits on the tonsils. However, this is not as adherent or classic as the membrane seen in diphtheria.

Diphtheria (Option B): Diphtheria is a hallmark condition associated with the formation of a grey-white pseudomembrane over the tonsils, which is firmly adherent and bleeds upon removal.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option D): Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can produce white or greyish exudates on the tonsils, especially in severe cases, alongside fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker’s oral examination. Identify the lesion given.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leukoplakia

Explanation:

  • Leukoplakia is characterised by a white patch or plaque on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off and cannot be attributed to another identifiable cause. It is commonly associated with chronic smoking, alcohol use, or other irritants. This lesion is considered a precancerous condition and warrants further evaluation and biopsy if necessary.

 

Definition

White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc.

Causes
  • Smoking, tobacco chewing
  • Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking)
  • Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites)
  • Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Common sites
  • Buccal mucosa (most common in India)
  • Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa

Age & Gender
  • Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females.

Clinical types
  • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk
  • Nodular (speckled): White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk
  • Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk

Malignant potential
  • 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation
  • Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations

Treatment
  • Remove causative factors: Spontaneous regression in some cases.
  • Biopsy: For lesions with high malignant potential.
  • Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy: For suspicious or small lesions

 

Erythroplakia (Option A): Erythroplakia presents as a red patch on the oral mucosa, often velvety in appearance, and is also a precancerous lesion. However, the lesion in this case is white, not red.

Fordyce’s granules (Option C): These are small, yellow or whitish papules representing ectopic sebaceous glands. They are benign and not related to smoking. They do not appear as a white patch like leukoplakia.

Koplik’s spots (Option D): Koplik’s spots are small white lesions with a red halo, typically seen on the buccal mucosa during the early stages of measles (rubeola). They are not associated with chronic smoking.

questions.text: What is the primary source of arterial supply for the palatine tonsils among the options provided?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

Explanation:

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the primary arterial supply to the palatine tonsils. The facial artery provides a direct tonsillar branch that supplies the tonsillar bed and adjacent structures.

 

Anatomy of Palatine tonsils

Location

Lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

Surface Extensions

Upwards into the soft palate, downwards into the base of the tongue, and anteriorly into the palatoglossal arch.

Medial Surface Epithelium
  • Stratified squamous epithelium with crypts.
  • Crypta magna, or intratonsillar cleft, is located near the upper part of the tonsil.

Lateral Surface

It is covered by a fibrous capsule separated from the tonsil bed by loose areolar tissue.

Tonsil Bed Muscles

Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

Arterial Supply
  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (main supply)
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Dorsal linguae branches of the lingual artery
  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.

Venous Drainage

It drains into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal venous plexus.

Lymphatic Drainage

Flows into the upper deep cervical nodes.

Sensory Nerve Supply

Lesser palatine branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion (CN V) and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery (Option B): This artery supplies the palate, including the soft and hard palates, but it is not the main source of blood supply for the palatine tonsils.

Buccal branch of maxillary artery (Option C): This artery primarily supplies the buccinator muscle and cheek mucosa, not the palatine tonsils.

Ascending palatine branch of facial artery (Option D): Although it contributes to the vascularisation of the pharyngeal region, it is not the primary supplier of the tonsils.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
• Adenoid facies, also known as adenoid face or long-face syndrome, refers to a characteristic facial appearance associated with chronic enlargement of the adenoids. Adenoid facies is characterized by specific facial features, which may include:
    • Long and narrow face
    • Open-mouth posture
    • High-arched palate
    • Dental crowding


 

Adenoid Hypertrophy: (Enlargement of the adenoids)

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
  • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
  • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
  • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
  • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.
 
  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph: This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

 

Goldenhar syndrome (Option B): Goldenhar syndrome, also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral spectrum (OAVS) or hemifacial microsomia, is a rare congenital condition that affects the development of structures on one side of the face. The most prominent feature of Goldenhar syndrome is craniofacial asymmetry. This can involve facial asymmetry, microtia (underdeveloped or absent external ear), and facial clefts such as cleft lip and palate.

 

Horse facies (Option C): Also known as Greek warrior helmet appearance, is seen in Treacher Collins syndrome. It is characterized by a short philtrum, a downturned mouth, Small chin (micrognathia), and Poorly formed ears with small holes (pits) or flaps of skin (tags).


Frog facies (Option D): The term is often used to describe the facial features observed in individuals with juvenile nasal angiofibroma. Broadening of the nasal bridge, swelling of cheek, frog face deformity (in cases of bilateral proptosis).

questions.text: Involvement of Jugular foramen leads to which of the following:

choices.text: Loss of taste from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue
Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue
Loss of sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue
Loss of tasteand sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue

Explanation:

Damage to the jugular foramen can compress or injure the glossopharyngeal nerve, leading to loss of both taste and sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue.

  • The tongue is divided into two regions:
    • Anterior two-thirds, innervated by the chorda tympani nerve (Option C)
    • Posterior one-third, supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, separated by the Sulcus terminalis.
  • Dysfunction in either of these nerves can cause impaired taste perception and loss of taste, as each nerve is responsible for sensation in its respective area.

Development of tongue and nerve innervation

Aspects

Anterior ⅔ of tongue

Two lingual swellings and a tuberculum impar, made from the mesoderm of 1st arch, fuse to form the anterior ⅔ of tongue.

The hypobranchial arch is formed by the mesoderm of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches and is further divided into cranial and caudal parts. The cranial part of this arch gives rise to the posterior ⅓.

The Caudal parts derived from the hypobranchial arch develop to the posterior part of the tongue

questions.text: What would be your immediate course of action in managing a patient who is experiencing bleeding from the surgical site following a tonsillectomy while in the recovery room?

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a serious complication that can lead to airway obstruction and significant blood loss. The immediate priority is to secure the airway and control the bleeding. The best course of action is to:

  1. Shift the patient to the operating theater (OT) for better visualization.
  2. Remove clots to identify the bleeding source.
  3. Cauterize or ligate the bleeding vessel to achieve hemostasis.

This is especially crucial in primary post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage (within 24 hours of surgery), which is usually due to inadequate hemostasis during the initial procedure.

Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa (Option B): Incorrect because while IV antibiotics may be necessary in cases of secondary hemorrhage (after 24 hours, often due to infection), primary hemorrhage requires immediate surgical intervention rather than just packing.

Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours (Option C): Incorrect because anticoagulants would worsen the bleeding, and gargling is ineffective in stopping active hemorrhage. Waiting 24 hours without intervention could lead to life-threatening blood loss and airway compromise.

Do blood transfusion and wait and watch (Option D): Incorrect because while a blood transfusion may be needed in severe cases, it does not stop the active bleeding. Immediate surgical control is essential.

questions.text: A senior resident in the hospital is performing the following clinical examination, as shown in the image below. Which of the following structures will not be visible to him?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Arytenoids

Explanation:

  • Arytenoids: The arytenoid cartilage is located in the larynx and is not visible during a posterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity and nasopharynx using a mirror or endoscope.
  • The arytenoids are situated lower down in the larynx and are not accessible through the posterior nasal passage.

Posterior Rhinoscopy:

  • Posterior rhinoscopy is a clinical examination technique used to visualize the posterior part of the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, and adjacent structures like the adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate.
  • This procedure is typically performed with a mirror or flexible endoscope, allowing the examiner to assess the nasopharyngeal area for any abnormalities.
  • Structures located in the nasopharynx and upper airway, but not the larynx, will be visible.

Incorrect Options:

Adenoids (Option A): are visible during posterior rhinoscopy, as they are located in the nasopharynx, which is the area examined in this procedure.

Torus tubarius (Option C): is the elevation of the mucosa over the eustachian tube orifice and is also visible during posterior rhinoscopy, being located in the nasopharynx.

Upper surface of soft palate (Option D): is visible during posterior rhinoscopy as it is part of the posterior oropharyngeal area and can be observed during the examination.
